name: Erdős–Menger conjecture
rephrased: In any infinite graph, if there are two distinct sets of vertices, there exist infinitely many vertex-disjoint paths connecting them, and a way to 'separate' these paths by selecting one vertex from each path.
implication_form: If G is an infinite graph and A, B are two distinct vertex sets in G, then there exist infinitely many vertex-disjoint A-B paths, and there exists a set of vertices (one from each path) that separates these paths.
explained: The Erdős–Menger conjecture states: For any infinite graph G and any two distinct vertices or vertex sets A and B in G, there exists a collection of vertex-disjoint paths connecting A to B, and there also exists a corresponding set of vertices (called an A-B separator) that intersects each of these paths exactly once. This conjecture provided a profound extension of Menger's theorem from finite to infinite graphs and was later proven to be true, becoming the Erdős–Menger theorem.
related_conjectures: Theorems on vertex connectivity and edge connectivity
